comments.article: Game of Thrones hit #10 (mass market paperback) on the NYT Bestseller List recently, as well. Good times!

I'm really sorry to say that, but that's the impression I got when I read it in Portuguese. I'm quite familiar with the original in English, where the text flows so smoothly that it doesn't become tiresome. Unfortunately, that's not what happened here in Brazil. The translator has adopted a style that is way too distant from the original. The reading is heavy and the words are difficult (I couldn't understand some of them, which didn't happen when I read it in English - and I'm Brazilian!). When I heard about a national version, I expected something quite different from what we got here. But, anyway, new readers don't seem troubled by that. The ones I know are getting really deep into the series, and becoming huge fans like me. It just seems to me they'll have different feelings about the books, like something more distant and old-styled.

comments.article:
Todo bem!

When I first met my longtime partner I introduced him to your books, and he loves them now as much as I do. Now I can introduce them to his mother (she is from Bahia) as well!

I was going to say the same thing about the translation in Brazil... The text lacks emotion, lacks continuity... I thought in abandon the reading many times, but I though it was an original book fault rather then an translation one. I am glad to see it maybe is just a bad translation, I'll try to read the book in english and see the difference...
I enjoyed it a bit, but looked very boring and with a bad flow... The story idea is very good, as well as the way the author creates the story elements, it looks like a web and (if you are read it carefully) you can see why it looks so interesting...

You should be in contact with LEYA, and try to negociate a new or better translation... I'm sure you could get more fans to your book series with a more carefully made one...
comments.subject: Brazilian Translation ...

comments.article:
First of all excuse for "google translate" English.

What happened is: Leya got the text in Portuguese of Portugal made by Jorge Candeias, and adapted without knowledge of the original text in English and without consulting the Candeias, the result was poor and generated responses from fans on the Internet that had read the original text and Jorge Candeias who posted on his blog about all this.

The important thing is Leya took this into account and the second book is already made upon the translation of Candeias, but is much (muuuuuuch) better adaptated
